screening_metadata.method: Multi-factor screening: Baumol score (avg_pay / $72,608 economy avg), fragmentation proxy (estabs/employment), employment scale, employment growth/decline, wage growth. Cross-referenced against engine state to exclude covered sectors. Scoring logic derived from connectors/sector_screener.py composite methodology.

scoring_weights.baumol_score: Primary filter. >=1.5 = high stored disruption energy
scoring_weights.wage_growth: Above-CPI wage growth = widening AI advantage

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Information (overall sector)
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: Highest Baumol score of any uncovered 2-digit sector (2.13x economy average). Nearly 3M workers with declining employment (-2.3%) and surging wages (+6.7%). Contains the epicenter of AI disruption across multiple sub-sectors: software publishing (NAICS 5132, Baumol 2.76, 648K emp), internet publishing (5162, Baumol 3.30, 226K emp, -6.4% decline), computing infrastructure (518, Baumol 2.36, 486K emp, +4.1% growth), and web/data services (519, Baumol 3.72, 183K emp). Motion pictures sub-sector (512) saw -13.9% employment decline. The sector is BOTH the engine of AI disruption AND a target of it. Sub-sector divergence (some growing, some collapsing) makes this the richest deep-dive territory outside the already-completed sectors.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: Information sector is bifurcating: AI infrastructure (518, 519) accelerating while content creation (512, 516) contracts. Software publishing (513) faces existential pressure from AI code generation. The sector's high wages create massive Baumol cure potential. Deep dive should model the internal reallocation: which sub-sectors absorb displaced workers, which become AI-augmented, and which face structural employment decline. Second-order: as information sector transforms, it changes the tools available to every other sector.

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Software Publishers
sub_sector_breakdown.note: AI code generation directly threatens this sub-sector. 648K workers at $200K avg pay = $130B addressable labor cost.

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Internet Publishing & Web Search
sub_sector_breakdown.note: Already contracting. AI-generated content replacing human content creation. Wage growth +16.4% even as employment falls = classic Baumol squeeze.

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Web Search Portals, Libraries, Archives, and Other Information Services
sub_sector_breakdown.note: Includes data processing, web portals. Sub-sector 519290 has Baumol 4.25, $309K avg pay. AI is both tool and threat.

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Computing Infrastructure Providers, Data Processing, Web Hosting
sub_sector_breakdown.note: GROWING sub-sector. AI compute demand driving expansion. Grid bottleneck (F6) is binding constraint.

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Motion Picture and Sound Recording
sub_sector_breakdown.note: Massive employment collapse (-14%). Hollywood strikes + AI content generation. 512110 (motion picture production) down -24.1%.

sub_sector_breakdown.title: Publishing Industries and Telecommunications
sub_sector_breakdown.note: Largest information sub-sector by employment. Includes telecom, which is capital-intensive with AI optimization opportunity.

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Securities, Commodity Contracts, and Other Financial Investments and Related Activities
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: While NAICS 52 (Financial Services) has a deep dive, the 523 sub-sector (securities/investments) deserves its own deep dive as a DISTINCT transformation story. Baumol 3.71 is one of the highest of any sector with >1M workers. 148K establishments (extreme fragmentation for finance). Wages DECLINING (-2.4%) while employment GROWS (+4.1%) — unusual divergence suggesting structural shift from high-paid human traders to lower-cost AI-augmented operations. Sub-sector 523940 (portfolio management/investment advice) has 496K workers, Baumol 3.72, and 84,880 establishments — the most fragmented high-wage sub-sector in the economy. 523160 (commodity contracts intermediation) has Baumol 4.50. This is where the financial cascade hits hardest.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: Securities/investment advisory is the most vulnerable high-wage sector to AI displacement. 496K workers in portfolio management at $270K avg pay doing work that AI can increasingly automate (analysis, allocation, reporting). The extreme fragmentation (85K establishments for 496K workers = avg 5.8 workers per firm) means thousands of small advisory firms face existential pressure. The RIA (Registered Investment Advisor) rollup wave + AI tools could collapse this structure. Deep dive should model the advisor-to-AI transition timeline and the wealth management industry's restructuring.
top_deep_dive_candidates.note: Technically under NAICS 52 umbrella but FS deep dive focused on banking cascade. Securities/investments is a distinct transformation warranting separate analysis.

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Management of Companies and Enterprises
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: 2.55M workers at $147K average pay — this is corporate headquarters and holding company employment. Baumol 2.02 with $375B total payroll. Low fragmentation (avg 27 workers/establishment) reflects large corporate HQ operations. This sector represents the COMMAND AND CONTROL layer of the economy — the C-suites, strategy teams, and corporate planning functions that AI agents directly threaten. Unlike specific industry sectors, this cross-cuts every vertical. 551114 (corporate subsidiary management) alone has 2.46M workers. If AI agents can perform middle-management functions, this 2.55M-worker sector faces compression.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: Corporate headquarters represent the highest-concentration of routine-cognitive work at high pay levels. AI agents capable of strategic analysis, reporting, and coordination directly threaten middle management layers. Deep dive should model: (1) which HQ functions are AI-compressible vs irreducibly human, (2) the Coasean firm-size implications — if AI replaces coordination overhead, do firms need HQs at all?, (3) CRE second-order effects from HQ downsizing, (4) geographic concentration risk (NYC, SF, Chicago HQ corridors). The Silver Tsunami (F2) may accelerate as retiring executives are not replaced 1:1.

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Utilities
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: Utilities are the BINDING CONSTRAINT on AI scaling (F6 energy). 576K workers at $128K avg pay, growing at +3.9% (among fastest-growing sectors). Baumol 1.77 with total wages $74B. Sub-sector 22111 (electric power generation) Baumol 1.96, 152K workers, +6.1% growth. Nuclear renaissance (221113, Baumol 2.22, 38K workers). Solar electric power (221114) grew +51.6% YoY — the fastest-growing sub-sector in the entire QCEW dataset. Grid bottleneck (2,600 GW in queue) makes this sector the gatekeeper of AI transformation. Data center grid share projected 6-12% by 2030.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: Utilities sector is experiencing a dual transformation: (1) AI is transforming utility operations (grid optimization, predictive maintenance, demand forecasting), and (2) AI demand is fundamentally restructuring the energy generation mix. Solar employment up 51.6%, nuclear workforce expanding. Deep dive should model: the energy bottleneck timeline (when does grid capacity unlock AI scaling?), the generation mix shift, the workforce transition from fossil to renewable/nuclear, and the geographic winners/losers (Texas, Southeast, Gulf vs coal-dependent regions). The $929B CRE debt maturity creates secondary pressure on utility revenues from commercial customers.

sub_sector_highlights.title: Nuclear Electric Power Generation
sub_sector_highlights.note: Nuclear renaissance for AI data centers

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Real Estate and Rental and Leasing
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: 2.4M workers across 488K establishments — the MOST fragmented major sector in the economy (fragmentation proxy 0.204, avg 4.9 workers per establishment). This extreme fragmentation + moderate Baumol (1.03) creates a massive consolidation and AI-intermediation opportunity. Real estate is a critical second-order cascade target: office vacancy at 19-24% (record), $929B CRE debt maturing, and the FS cascade directly impacts commercial real estate through credit tightening. Sub-sector 531 (real estate) has 1.8M workers across 426K establishments. The Zillow/Redfin/AI agent wave is just beginning to restructure residential transactions while commercial faces structural vacancy.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: Real estate faces a two-front transformation: (1) Residential: AI agents replacing transaction intermediaries (agents, brokers, appraisers) in a sector with 488K establishments averaging <5 workers — peak fragmentation for AI rollup. (2) Commercial: structural vacancy from remote work + AI workforce reduction creating a repricing cascade. Deep dive should model: the CRE debt maturity cascade ($929B), the residential AI agent displacement timeline, the geographic variation (Sun Belt vs. coastal office markets), and the PE refinancing wall impact on CRE-backed loans. The FS cascade (P-026) directly feeds into CRE through credit channels.

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extraction
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: 584K workers at $123K avg pay, growing +5.0% YoY with wages rising +4.4%. Sub-sector 211 (oil & gas extraction) has Baumol 2.84, 116K workers at $206K avg pay — among the highest-paid non-finance sectors. Natural gas (211120) has Baumol 3.05, 84K workers at $222K. This sector sits at the intersection of F6 (energy) and F3 (geopolitics). AI data center demand is driving natural gas pipeline investment. The oil-to-AI transition is reshaping energy economics. Mining (212) is growing +3-5% as critical minerals for AI hardware create new demand. The sector's high wages and moderate fragmentation create AI optimization opportunity.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: Mining/energy extraction is being transformed by two AI forces simultaneously: (1) AI optimization of extraction operations (autonomous drilling, predictive maintenance, geological modeling), and (2) AI compute demand fundamentally altering energy demand curves. Natural gas is the bridge fuel for AI data centers. Deep dive should model: the AI-driven energy demand curve, the pipeline bottleneck, autonomous mining operations timeline, critical mineral extraction for semiconductor supply chains, and the geographic concentration of AI-relevant energy assets. Gulf states' oil-to-AI conversion (P-031) provides international comparison.

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Computer Systems Design and Related Services
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: While technically under NAICS 54 (Professional Services), this 2.46M-worker sub-sector deserves standalone analysis. It is the LABOR MARKET for AI itself — the workers who build, deploy, and maintain AI systems. Baumol 2.05 with $367B total payroll. Employment flat (-0.4%) while wages surge (+5.0%) is a classic Baumol squeeze signal. Extreme fragmentation: 406K establishments for 2.46M workers (avg 6 workers/firm). Sub-sector 541511 (custom programming) has 1.1M workers at $164K avg. Sub-sector 541714 (R&D in physical/engineering/life sciences) has 290K workers at $213K, Baumol 2.93. The 25-40% of Google code being AI-generated directly threatens the largest sub-group (541511). This is the sector that disrupts itself.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: IT services is the sector most directly disrupted by the technology it produces. AI code generation (25-40% at Google) will compress custom programming demand. Deep dive should model: (1) which IT roles are AI-augmented vs AI-replaced, (2) the staffing firm collapse within IT (already visible in RHI/MAN canary), (3) the shift from project-based to product-based delivery, (4) India IT services impact (Infosys, TCS, Wipro employ millions). The extreme fragmentation (406K establishments) suggests massive small-firm shakeout. Agentic AI workflows may replace entire teams of 2-5 person IT consultancies.
top_deep_dive_candidates.note: Under NAICS 54 umbrella but deserves standalone analysis — it is 23% of all professional services employment

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Retail Trade
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: 15.5M workers — second-largest private sector employer after healthcare. Low Baumol (0.57) means low stored disruption energy, but the sheer SCALE makes even small percentage disruptions enormous (1% = 155K jobs). 1.07M establishments. Wage growth barely above inflation (+1.65%) signals labor commoditization. Retail is being reshaped by AI-powered e-commerce, autonomous checkout, inventory optimization, and AI-driven personalization. This sector has been under-analyzed in the engine despite its massive employment base. The Baumol floor thesis: retail wages are so low that AI displacement creates a different dynamic — not Baumol cure but labor reallocation to higher-value work or unemployment.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: Retail faces a different AI transformation than high-Baumol sectors. Rather than releasing stored cost energy, AI in retail drives: (1) store format transformation (autonomous stores, micro-fulfillment), (2) labor reallocation from cashiers/stock to customer experience, (3) e-commerce logistics optimization, (4) hyper-personalization. Deep dive should model: the employment impact curve (how many of 15.5M jobs face displacement by 2031?), the small retailer shakeout (1.07M establishments), and the geographic impact (retail is the largest employer in many rural counties). Low wages mean displaced workers have fewer transition options.

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: 2.5M workers growing at +7.7% (fastest-growing uncovered sector). The overall Baumol is low (0.68), but sub-sectors diverge dramatically: spectator sports (7112) has Baumol 2.80, 156K workers, +9.3% growth, $203K avg pay. Independent artists/performers (7115) has Baumol 2.09, 60K workers, extreme fragmentation (0.655), with wages FALLING -10.3%. Professional sports (711211) has Baumol 3.66, 109K workers at $266K avg pay, growing +11.8%. This is a Barbell Economy exemplar: elite entertainment performers see surging value while the middle collapses. AI-generated content (music, visual art, writing) is already restructuring the creative economy.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: Arts/entertainment is the clearest Barbell Economy sector: AI raises the ceiling for star performers (sports analytics, personalized content, global distribution) while collapsing the middle (stock photography, background music, routine content). Deep dive should model: (1) the creative economy bifurcation — which sub-sectors benefit vs. suffer, (2) the sports analytics/gambling intersection (driving the Baumol 2.80 in spectator sports), (3) AI-generated content impact on independent artists (7115 wages already -10.3%), (4) the psychology dimension — public resistance to AI-generated art may create trust premiums.

top_deep_dive_candidates.title: Other Services (except Public Administration)
top_deep_dive_candidates.screening_rationale: 4.6M workers across 880K establishments — second-most fragmented major sector (fragmentation 0.193, avg 5.2 workers per establishment). Includes auto repair, personal care, equipment repair, dry cleaning, and religious organizations. Low Baumol (0.70) but massive fragmentation creates the CLASSIC small-business AI rollup opportunity. This is the 'long tail' of the economy — millions of micro-firms doing tacit-manual and tacit-cognitive work. Sub-sector 811 (repair/maintenance) has 1.4M workers across 246K establishments. The Silver Tsunami (52.3% of businesses owned by 55+) hits this sector hardest because these are overwhelmingly owner-operated businesses. Combined with P-022 (Zero-Density Schumpeterian Gaps), this is a sector where transformation will be SUDDEN.
top_deep_dive_candidates.transformation_hypothesis: Other Services is the economy's blind spot — too fragmented and low-margin for traditional analysis, but representing 4.6M workers. AI transformation here looks different: not Baumol cure (wages are low) but operational AI (scheduling, billing, inventory, customer management) enabling micro-firm consolidation. Deep dive should model: (1) which sub-sectors face Silver Tsunami succession crises (auto repair shops, dry cleaners — owner-operators aging out), (2) the Micro-Firm OS opportunity (P-001 pattern from v2), (3) equipment repair transformation via IoT + predictive maintenance, (4) religious organizations (largest employer in 813) and their AI adoption trajectory.

cross_cutting_insights.AI_infrastructure_chain: NAICS 518 (compute) + 22 (utilities) + 21 (energy extraction) + 486 (pipelines) form an interconnected infrastructure chain. AI scaling is constrained by the slowest link. Deep dive on any one requires understanding the others.
cross_cutting_insights.barbell_economy_evidence: NAICS 71 (arts/entertainment) provides the clearest Barbell Economy data: sports teams (Baumol 3.66, +11.8% growth) vs independent artists (Baumol 2.09, wages -10.3%). The middle is collapsing while the extremes diverge.
cross_cutting_insights.fragmentation_consolidation_opportunity: Sectors with fragmentation >0.15 AND employment >100K represent the richest consolidation targets: Real Estate (53, frag 0.204, 2.4M emp), Other Services (81, frag 0.193, 4.6M emp), Professional Services sub-sectors (5415, frag 0.165, 2.5M emp), Software Publishers (5132, frag 0.137, 648K emp).
cross_cutting_insights.second_order_cascade_targets: The FS cascade (P-026) flows through: (1) CRE vacancy -> Real Estate (53), (2) credit tightening -> all PE-backed sectors, (3) branch closures -> retail real estate, (4) displaced financial workers -> retraining demand. Real Estate (53) is the primary second-order cascade receptor.
cross_cutting_insights.silver_tsunami_concentration: The Silver Tsunami (P-002) hits hardest in highly fragmented, owner-operated sectors: Other Services (81), Real Estate (53), Construction (23, already tracked). These are sectors where the business IS the owner. Succession + AI creates a unique acquisition + modernization window.
cross_cutting_insights.zero_density_gaps_uncovered: From P-022: Wholesale Trade (42, already tracked) has zero AI startups. Real Estate (53) and Other Services (81) likely have similar gaps at the sub-sector level. These are sectors where transformation will be SUDDEN when it starts.

v3-6_cycle: NAICS 51 - Information sector (highest Baumol uncovered, internal bifurcation, AI epicenter)
NAICS 22 - Utilities (binding constraint on AI scaling, F6 nexus, renewable energy transformation)
v3-7_cycle: NAICS 55 - Management of Companies (corporate HQ layer, Coasean firm-size implications)
NAICS 53 - Real Estate (FS cascade second-order receptor, extreme fragmentation, CRE crisis)
v3-8_cycle: NAICS 5415 - Computer Systems Design (the sector that disrupts itself, India offshoring impact)
NAICS 523 - Securities/Investments (standalone analysis beyond FS cascade, RIA rollup wave)
v3-9_cycle: NAICS 71 - Arts/Entertainment (Barbell Economy exemplar, AI-generated content)
NAICS 81 - Other Services (Silver Tsunami + micro-firm OS, long tail of economy)
recommended_deep_dive_sequence.rationale: Sequence prioritizes: (1) sectors with highest Baumol AND large employment first, (2) sectors that are binding constraints on other transformations (utilities), (3) second-order cascade receptors (real estate), (4) sectors that illustrate key framework concepts (barbell economy, zero-density gaps).
